GIL.raw_line: This is unbelievable - look at this. There's no city like this in the world. There never was.Well that's just the awful era we live in but can you just imagine what this was like before - but even with all the fast food joints and the traffic - god, you just can't imagine what it was like years ago.I really do - I love cities - I love big cities with all the crowds and all the action. CUT TO:Look at these places - the streets - the boulevards.I don't get here often enough is the problem. Every once in a while for a few days is nothing - my biggest regret is that I didn't settle here the first time I came. I should have gone with my instincts.If I'd have stayed the first time I came by now I'd be a Parisian.I'm thinking of a painting by Pisarro I've seen of Paris in the rain. Can you picture how drop dead gorgeous this city is in the rain? Imagine this town in the twenties - Paris in the twenties - in the rain - the artists and writers - I was born too late. Why did God deliver me into the world in the 1970's and in Pasadena yet.It's romantic.Or Paris when it's just getting dark - the lights go on - or at night - it's great at night - or no, sunset on the Champs Elysees -Could you ever think of us moving here after we're married? CUT TO:Like?Hawaii is America.If I had stayed here and written novels and not gotten into grinding out movie scripts.But this is where all the artists came to live, to work - the writers, the painters.Boy, I'd drop the house in Beverly Hills, the pool, everything - in a heartbeat. Look - this is where Monet lived and painted - we're thirty minutes from town. Imagine the two of us settling here. If my book turns out we could do it - you could just as easily make jewelry here. CUT TO:I'm in love with you. CUT TO:What a town.I could easily see myself as a Parisien - strolling the Left Bank - a baguette under my arm - finishing my novel - at a table at the Cafe Flore. A Moveable Feast - Hemingway called it. CONTWell yes it was different then.Americans eat dinner so early.You can't say they weren't right in not backing Bush's moronic war in Iraq.There's nothing wrong with your father and I disagreeing. That's what democracy is. Your father defends the right wing of the Republican party and I happen to think they represent sub-mental Neanderthals. But we respect each other's views - am I right?Just no Wagner. When she walks down the aisle not The Ride of the Valkyries. Hey look, I just want to say that I am politically bipartisan in that, in my view, to be a politician of any party one must of necessity be a whore.Don't we have a lot of commitments?Don't we have something tomorrow? We were going to have lunch at the Brasserie Lipp. My old professor once actually saw James Joyce there. He said Joyce was eating sauerkraut and frankfurters.It is actually -Yes - but -How was I anti-social?Well they're your friends and I can't say I'm as taken with him as you are.I find him a pseudo-intellectual.I'm having trouble because I'm a Hollywood hack who never gave actual literature a real shot.I keep trying to talk her into a little attic with a skylight in Paris - CONTYes movie scripts are easier.I don't like to discuss my work.I'm afraid she's right. I just read the recent two volume biography of Rodin - Rose was definitely the wife, Camille the mistress.I did - no question. Camille- Rose.Me? Why would I read a biography of Rodin? CUT TO:To me they're all great. What the hell do I know?Pheromones, it's your pheromones. Paul and Carol have ambled over, having heard Gil's last amorous remark.You will admit she's a sexy woman.To the little green Heinz pickle pin. CUT TO:I don't want to be a party pooper but I just want fresh air.If it's okay with you, I'd really just like a little walk and go to bed. We can do it another night.You go? CaNTO:I - I - guess so CUT TO:Huh?You have the wrong person.Look, I'm a little drunk -This is a great old peugeot. I have a friend in Beverly Hills who has the same one - he collects -Where are we going?It's not fair - my head is swimming from wine.I do like champagne.I'm drinking up. He drinks, befuddled. CUT TO:You're American.Oh I - I'm a writer.Right now I'm working on a novel.California.I'm Gil Pen - oh you two have the same names as - CONTScott Fitzgerald and -Yes - its a coincidence. I mean it is a funny coincidence.I - I - I keep thinking that man at the piano - believe it or not I recognize his face from some old sheet music - what am I talking about here?Yes but - he didn't write that song - did he? That's not possible -I - I - I - I'm - I'm working on a - exactly where am I?Hey lady, are you kidding me?Gil Pender.Hemingway? Hey, is this some kind of a -Liked - I loved - everything you wrote -Ernest Hemingway - this is - I -I'm sure - good bulls, true bullsMe? I just met -Actually I don't know the Fitzgeralds that well -I do - very much.No.A novel.A man who works in a nostalgia shop.Where they sell old things - memorabilia. Does that sound terrible to you?Would you do me the biggest favor in the world - I can't even askWould you read it?It's only about four hundred pages - if you could just give me your opinion.You do?But there's no one I really trust to evaluate it -I could never compete with you - CONTNo - no - that's okay -Yes?You could have Gertrude Stein read my novel?I have to get it. To have Gertrude Stein read my novel - thank you, thank you - He exits the place.Calm yourself - get a grip, Gil - deep breaths - been quite a night - Fitzgerald - Hemingway - the Hemingway - Papa - where do I meet him - he never said. Gil goes to return to the cafe - he can't find the door, nor the club facade. It's gone. We are in the present and he searches the wall of a facade where he came out but he is in despair over the fact he can't find it. CUT TO:Uh-huh.If I told you I was with Ernest Hemingway and Scott Fitzgerald last night, what would you say?But if I wasn't dreaming -If I told you I spent time with Hemingway and Fitzgerald and Cole Porter -Can I tell you Zelda Fitzgerald is exactly as we've come to know her from articles and books - she's mercurial and moody and she does not get along with Hemingway - and Scott knows Hemingway's right about it but you can see how conflicted he is because he loves her -Actually I wanted to stay and work on my novel - it needs a little polishing.Eighteen thousand dollars?Yes but we haven't even found a house yet and I'm trying to keep expenses down so I can turn down jobs.I know you love Malibu but -Er - of course when you think of it that way it does help amortize the eighteen grand.And after I have a terrific surprise for you. It's more of a petit bourgeoise statement of how Pablo er Picasso sees her, saw her - he's distracted by the fact she was a volcano in the sack. CUT TO:I was at Gertrude Stein's - she's almost finished with my novel. And the Fitzgeralds invited me over and said you'd be here - you and Pablo.That was Djuna Barnes? CUT TO:I hope it was nothing serious with you and Pablo?I understand why they all want to paint you - you're so damn interesting to look at in a lovely way.I don't want to talk about my book. I know it's shallow.Well, that's the most interesting thing I've ever heard in my life - I'd like to think about that for awhile. CUT TO:Because he believes in his soul that progress is not automatically for the better.Say - is that who I think it is?Scott loves only you. I can tell you with absolute certainty.No you're wrong. I never thought about it.I'm sure I look sad.
